title: More than 1,100 young people have already enrolled for voluntary military service information session
first_lines: The Belgian Defence Minister Theo Francken (Flemish nationalist) says that more than 1,100 young people have already registered for an information session about voluntary military service. The Belgian Defence Ministry has sent letters to all 17-year-olds in Belgium asking them if they wish to do year’s voluntary military service. The first of the letters arrived on Wednesday.
content: There are 500 voluntary military service places available. Those that take part will start their training in September 2026.

In just three days, more than 1,100 young people,  have already registered for an information session on voluntary military service. Of these 626 are Dutch-speakers and 480 are Francophones. Attendance at information session (1 will be held in each province) is mandatory before a candidate can resister for the military training that they must do in order to participate in the voluntary military service scheme.
The first information session will take place in Ghent (East Flanders) on Saturday 22 November.
In the summer of 2026, the ranking will be published based on the results of the selection procedure. The best 500 candidates will then receive an invitation to start.

title: Belgians taking fewer antibiotics
first_lines: According to a new report by the public health science institute Sciensano, the use of antibiotics in Belgium has fallen by 14% during the past 10 years. Sciensano describes this development as “encouraging”, but at the same time stresses that the European targets are not currently being met.
content: Antibiotics are medicines used to fight bacteria. However, excessive or incorrect use of antibiotics can lead to resistance, meaning that bacterial infections become much more difficult or even impossible to treat.
The European Union has therefore set a target of reducing the number of daily doses per 1,000 population to 17.5 by 2030. However, according to Sciensano, we are still a long way from achieving this.
In 2023, the consumption of antibiotics in Belgium stood at 20.6 daily doses per 1,000 population. If current trends continue, the European targets will not be met.

The Sciensano report also shows that on average the use of antibiotics in hospitals has increased in recent years. However, its use for the treatment of outpatients has actually decreased. Sciensano concludes that “Harmonising practices between hospitals could contribute to a more rational use of antibiotics”.

title: Former European commissioner Didier Reynders charged with money laundering
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Didier Reynders (Francophone liberal MR), the former Belgian cabinet minister, who also served as the Belgian on the European Commission has been officially charged with money laundering, media outlets De Standaard, Le Soir, Le Vif and the Dutch investigative platform Follow The Money report. Judicial sources have confirmed the news to the VRT. Reynders is said to have been questioned by investigators on 16 October.
content: In December last year, it emerged that a judicial investigation had been opened into possible money laundering practices by the former Belgian finance, justice and foreign minister.

Reynders is alleged to have used cash to buy National Lottery scratch cards for many years in order to see the profits laundered back into his account. The matter has come to a head after the National Lottery reported suspected money laundering to the competent authorities in 2022.
The money laundering investigation also looked at the regular deposit of large sums of cash at a bank. The total amount involved suspicious transactions said to be up to 1 million euros.
Almost a year after the case came to light, Reynders has now been officially charged. Reynders's wife, former senior magistrate Bernadette Prignon, has not been charged De Standaard writes.

Didier Reynders is alleged to have bought National Lottery tickets using cash for years, for a total amount of up to 200,000 euros. He deposited the winnings into his account allowing the money to be laundered.

The investigation also looked at sums of cash that Reynders deposited into an ING account between 2008 and 2018. These were relatively small amounts but totalled 700,000 euros. Together with the amounts for scratch cards, approximately 1 million euros is involved in all.

The Brussels Public Prosecutor's Office is conducting a separate investigation into the role in this case played by Dutch bank ING. The bank only queried the deposits for a first time in 2018 and only informed the Financial Intelligence Processing Unit (CFI) in 2023. Normally, banks are required to report suspicious transactions immediately.

title: Government crisis in the offing?
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Belgian premier Bart De Wever’s deadline of Thursday for agreement on a multi-year budget is approaching fast.  The premier has set a goal of ‘finding’ 10 billion euros either through new taxes or government cuts, but last night federal coalition partners parted ways without agreement.  Bilateral talks between the PM and deputy premiers representing each of the parties in the 5-way coalition continue Wednesday.
content: At around 9 p.m., the federal ministers parted ways without reaching an agreement.

‘The temperature of the atmosphere has dropped well below freezing,’ one source told VRT News. Several sources point to the attitude of the Francophone liberal MR, which they claim seems unwilling to reach an agreement, as the reason. The party is opposing a VAT hike and higher taxes for Belgium's wealthiest, but has now reportedly also indicated which measures it believes could raise cash. The coalition partners also took issue with a planned visit by MR leader Georges-Louis Bouchez to Unizo East Flanders on Wednesday. Bouchez also invited the press to attend his visit to the local federation for the self-employed, on the eve of the crucial budget deadline.

The MR leader's tweets, in which he clashed with N-VA chair Valerie Van Peel on social media, did not help the atmosphere either. In a video posted on social media, Van Peel had called it ‘unbelievable’ that some fellow party leaders did not recognise the urgency of the situation and ‘did not dare to step out of their own shadow’.

If no deal can be reached by the deadline PM De Wever may visit King Filip to tender his resignation.  It then remains to be seen if the monarch will accept his premier’s offer or in true Belgian style will send him back to the negotiating table in the hope of still thrashing out a deal.

title: Belgium to beef up airspace security
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: “We have the situation under control” Belgian home and security minister Bernard Quintin (Francophone liberal) told international media after Thursday’s unscheduled meeting of Belgium’s security council.  The meeting was called after unidentified drones caused disruption at airports and military bases across Belgium in recent days.  Belgian security services blame Russia for the disruption.
content: After the meeting Quintin called for calm: “If the police want to be able to do something, there must be a clear legal framework for it. It is our job as politicians to look into that,” the minister said.

He emphasised that there is a mandatory registration system for drones and their pilots. "We do not live in a system where everyone can do whatever they want. We cannot ban all drones, because we also need them for our security.
“But I want to emphasize that you can get 10 to 20 years in prison if you fly a drone over the airport and endanger safety.”
Quintin provided reassurance: “We really do have the situation under control. The threat is there, I won't deny that, but we are certainly not completely left to our own devices.”
After the security  council meeting Belgian defence minister Francken (Flemish nationalist) announced the decision to strengthen the NASC, the National Air Security Center by 1 January.

"The NASC in Beauvechain (Walloon Brabant) will be strengthened by 1 January. This is the most important measure taken at the National security council meeting", defense minister Francken noted upon leaving the meeting.
“All security services together must obtain a global picture of the airspace,” he said. The NASC must ensure this.
The purchase of anti-drone equipment was also discussed, he said. He is now working on that dossier so that it can be presented to cabinet tomorrow.
“In the meantime, no hostile drones should be allowed on our territory or above our military bases. The mission and guidelines are clear: if possible, we will shoot them down!”

title: Federal Government wants lifetime ban on entry to Belgium for convicted terrorists and hate preachers
first_lines: At a meeting on Friday the Federal Cabinet decided that convicted terrorists and hate preachers that are residing in Belgium illegally may soon be subject to a lifetime ban on entering the country. Currently, bans on entering the country can only be imposed for a set period.
content: Speaking after Friday morning’s cabinet meeting, the Federal Asylum and Migration Minister Anneleen Van Bossuyt (Flemish nationalist) said that “The door will be permanently closed to those that radicalise or support terrorism”.

Ms Van Bossuyt cited convicted terrorists, potentially violent extremists, and hate preachers as examples of those that would be affected by the ban. In order to ensure an objective assessment of the security risk, any decision to ban an individual from the country will always be preceded by an analysis by the terror threat level assessment body OCAD, Ms Van Bossuyt added.
People banned from entering Belgium will be flagged in both the Schengen Information System and the national police database.

Meanwhile, the Asylum and Migration Minister also says that the number of undocumented migrants that were serving time in Belgians prisons but have been sent back to their countries of origin has increased in recent months. In the first 10 months of this year 1,300 were sent back. This compares to 1,035 in the same period last year.

Ms Van Bossuyt says that she intends to build on this trend by increasing the number of places available in secure asylum centres. More repatriation escorts will be taken on and more effective readmission agreements made with countries of origin.

"Anyone who commits criminal offences or poses a threat to our society must leave the country. By focusing more on returning those serving custodial sentences we are protecting our society and giving our overburdened prison system more breathing space."
Prison overcrowding has been an issue in Belgium for a number of years. Around a third of prisoners in Belgian jails are undocumented.

title: Belgian cabinet approves drone defence plan
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: The Belgian cabinet has now approved the counter-drone plan that defence minister Theo Francken (Flemish nationalist N-VA) proposed.
content: The minister made the announcement on X. Friday afternoon, the cabinet reached an agreement in principle on the drone defence plan. However, the final green light had not yet been given, as “a number of options” still had to be considered.
Francken's announcement means that approval has now been granted. ‘Counter-drone plan just approved by the cabinet,’ he writes.
The plan provides for the purchase of detection equipment and systems to shoot down drones, according to the post. ‘The safety of our airports and military domains is an absolute priority.’

title: “Act responsibly and bridge your differences”, King Filip urges
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: The royal palace has issued a press release on behalf of Filip, King of Belgians, after the Belgian head of state met with prime minister Bart De Wever (Flemish nationalist) amid the deepening budget crisis.  Belgium’s 5-way federal coalition government is struggling to finalise a multi-year budget as demanded by the PM.
content: According to the statement "the prime minister informed the king that there are ongoing differences of opinion within his government about the budget, but that the coalition partners want to continue their work. The king took note of the prime minister's findings and urged all parties involved to act with responsibility and bridge their differences so that the country can as soon as possible have a clear budgetary path for the coming years".
The king is not setting any deadlines. But PM De Wever has agreed with key ministers that the budget must be finalised by the Christian feast of Christmas on 25 December, a public holiday in Belgium.

Next year’s budget needs to be approved by parliament in time.  Otherwise, key reforms won’t be able to start from the beginning of next year and Belgium will be obliged to operate using a temporary monthly budget that allocates a twelfth of this year’s spending to each month at the beginning of 2026.
Measures that will be delayed include some pension reforms and the introduction of the new capital gains tax.

title: Bill White is the new US Ambassador to Brussels
first_lines: Bill White is the new American ambassador to Brussels. Ambassador White has already presented his credentials to Belgium’s Head of State King Filip (photo above). Bill White is the founder of a consultancy firm. He donated to Donald Trump's election campaign, but previously also offered financial backing to the Democrats Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton. He is openly gay and in a same-sex marriage.
content: The US President Donald Trump appointed the businessman Bill White as the new United States' ambassador to Belgium in December 2024. Following Senate approval and a swearing-in ceremony at the US State Department, Mr White arrived in Belgium on 6 November. On Thursday, he presented his credentials to King Filip at the Royal Palace and the US Embassy in Brussels officially announced his appointment.

In a press statement, Bill White said that it was a great honour to represent the Trump Administration in Belgium. “I look forward to working closely with our Belgian friends to promote peace and security in Europe and further strengthen our economic ties that create prosperity for Americans and Belgians alike.”
The news website Politico says that Bill White was a major donor to Trump's election campaign. Despite this, in the past, Mr White supported the Democrats Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton.
In 2012 the openly gay Mr White, publicly withdrew his support for the Republican Mitt Romney, describing him as “on the wrong side of history”, due to his stance on same-sex marriage.
